citations.narrative:
An acquisition record for a domestic rabbit was not available for review at time of inspection. The record of animals on
hand was not updated to reflect changes in animal numbers for the following species: domestic cattle, blackbuck, wallaby,
domestic goat, domestic sheep, llama, Asiatic water buffalo, common parakeet, laughing kookaburra, domestic duck,
domestic turkey and domestic rabbits. Appropriate documentation of regulated animals is essential for proper
identification, tracking of animals and for APHIS Officials to be able to carry out their duties. Exhibitors shall make and
maintain complete records regarding the details of the acquisition and disposition of animals in their possession in order
to account for all animal transfers and the sources of the animals.
Correct by 09 August 2024.

The review of the contingency plan had been conducted over a year ago at time of inspection. Failure to regularly review
the contingency plan may result in out-of-date information, delays in emergency response and subsequent injury to
animals. The plan must be reviewed by the exhibitor on at least an annual basis to ensure that it adequately addresses
the criteria listed in paragraph (a) of this section. Each licensee must maintain documentation of their annual reviews,
including documenting any amendments or changes made to their plan since the previous year's review. Review
documentation must be made available to APHIS upon request.
Correct by 09 August 2024.

citations.desc: Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being.
citations.narrative:
The nonhuman primate environmental enhancement plan was not available for review during inspection. Failure to follow
or have available for review an appropriate plan for environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being of
nonhuman primates impedes APHIS Officials' ability to carry out their duties. Exhibitors must develop, document and
follow an appropriate plan for environment enhancement adequate to promote the psychological well-being of nonhuman
primates as directed by the attending veterinarian and the plan must be made available to APHIS upon request.
Correct by 09 August 2024.

There is a large amount of standing water in approximately 1/4 of the outdoor enclosure for 8 domestic goats, 8 domestic
sheep and 1 domestic pig where the animals must walk through mud or standing water to access 1 of 2 feed bins. The
other feed bin is on dry ground. The outdoor enclosure for 4 zebu has standing water or thick mud surrounding most of
the water trough. There is a small section of dry ground animals may use to access the water. These animals appeared
alert and apparently healthy during inspection. Failure to provide rapid elimination of excess water in outdoor primary
enclosures may negatively impact animal health and welfare by causing their discomfort or contribute to disease
processes such as hoof care issues. A suitable method shall be provided to rapidly eliminate excess water in outdoor
facilities. Corrected during inspection.
Correct from this date forward of 10 July 2024.

There are 39 adult domestic ducks in an outdoor enclosure that do not have adequate shelter space for all animals
housed to seek refuge from inclement weather. Failure to provide shelter from adverse weather for outdoor housed birds
may result in their discomfort or poor health. Outdoor housing facilities must provide adequate shelter, appropriate to the
species and physical conditions of the birds, for the local climatic conditions to protect the birds from any adverse weather
conditions and to prevent their discomfort from direct sunlight, precipitation or wind. Shelters must be constructed to
provide sufficient space to comfortably hold all of the birds at the same time without adverse intraspecific aggression or
grouping of incompatible birds. Corrected at time of inspection.
Correct from this date forward of 10 July 2024.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representatives.
n

narrative:
2.75(b)(1) 
   
Records: Dealers and exhibitors. 
An acquisition record for a domestic rabbit was not available for review at time of inspection. The record of animals on 
hand was not updated to reflect changes in animal numbers for the following species: domestic cattle, blackbuck, wallaby, 
domestic goat, domestic sheep, llama, Asiatic water buffalo, common parakeet, laughing kookaburra, domestic duck, 
domestic turkey and domestic rabbits. Appropriate documentation of regulated animals is essential for proper 
identification, tracking of animals and for APHIS Officials to be able to carry out their duties. Exhibitors shall make and 
maintain complete records regarding the details of the acquisition and disposition of animals in their possession in order 
to account for all animal transfers and the sources of the animals. 
 
Correct by 09 August 2024. 
2.134(b) 
   
Contingency planning. 
The review of the contingency plan had been conducted over a year ago at time of inspection. Failure to regularly review 
the contingency plan may result in out-of-date information, delays in emergency response and subsequent injury to 
animals. The plan must be reviewed by the exhibitor on at least an annual basis to ensure that it adequately addresses 
the criteria listed in paragraph (a) of this section. Each licensee must maintain documentation of their annual reviews, 
including documenting any amendments or changes made to their plan since the previous year's review. Review 
documentation must be made available to APHIS upon request. 
 
Correct by 09 August 2024. 
3.81 
   
Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being. 
The nonhuman primate environmental enhancement plan was not available for review during inspection. Failure to follow 
or have available for review an appropriate plan for environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being of 
nonhuman primates impedes APHIS Officials' ability to carry out their duties. Exhibitors must develop, document and 
follow an appropriate plan for environment enhancement adequate to promote the psychological well-being of nonhuman

primates as directed by the attending veterinarian and the plan must be made available to APHIS upon request. 
 
Correct by 09 August 2024. 
3.127(c) 
   
Facilities, outdoor. 
There is a large amount of standing water in approximately 1/4 of the outdoor enclosure for 8 domestic goats, 8 domestic 
sheep and 1 domestic pig where the animals must walk through mud or standing water to access 1 of 2 feed bins. The 
other feed bin is on dry ground. The outdoor enclosure for 4 zebu has standing water or thick mud surrounding most of 
the water trough. There is a small section of dry ground animals may use to access the water. These animals appeared 
alert and apparently healthy during inspection. Failure to provide rapid elimination of excess water in outdoor primary 
enclosures may negatively impact animal health and welfare by causing their discomfort or contribute to disease 
processes such as hoof care issues. A suitable method shall be provided to rapidly eliminate excess water in outdoor 
facilities. Corrected during inspection.  
 
Correct from this date forward of 10 July 2024. 
3.152(b) 
   
Facilities, outdoor 
There are 39 adult domestic ducks in an outdoor enclosure that do not have adequate shelter space for all animals 
housed to seek refuge from inclement weather. Failure to provide shelter from adverse weather for outdoor housed birds 
may result in their discomfort or poor health. Outdoor housing facilities must provide adequate shelter, appropriate to the 
species and physical conditions of the birds, for the local climatic conditions to protect the birds from any adverse weather 
conditions and to prevent their discomfort from direct sunlight, precipitation or wind. Shelters must be constructed to 
provide sufficient space to comfortably hold all of the birds at the same time without adverse intraspecific aggression or 
grouping of incompatible birds. Corrected at time of inspection. 
 
Correct from this date forward of 10 July 2024. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representatives.
